I think this is the key mistake that people make, and why so many people seemed to be bothered by the nature of crit.

There's no such thing as "deserved victory", people either win or they lose. 

Even in real life sports sometimes luck just goes against you. Chance makes things more interesting overall, since otherwise matches are predictable and boring - I mean, when was the last time you watched a video of a chess tournament?

In chess, I find that in about 4/5 games the more skilled player wins. In sports it's the same thing. The game isn't about who gets the most luck in their favor, it's about who is strategically and skillfully the better team. If I am playing baseball and winning, and a ball of hail falls right on my noggin while I'm about to catch a ball, the enemy team doesn't deserve to profit from that, because the advantage they gained was not made by their team in any way.

This game is arguably less about strategy than a certain competitor, but has far less rng. Comparing a one on one strategy game like chess to a team game MOBA would only make sense if you could only control one piece for the entire game. Would you consider a lapse in logic rng where the unfortunate shouldn't lose? It doesn't happen every game and happens randomly. Even the best of the best have a chance of slipping.

>If I am playing baseball and winning, and a ball of hail falls right on my noggin while I'm about to catch a ball, the enemy team doesn't deserve to profit from that, because the advantage they gained was not made by their team in any way.

Yes they should, because it has just as much chance to hit them as it did you, especially when you realize you're playing in an area that hail can fall unexpectedly. Besides, you lost your focus based on something you knew might happen. Why should they not capitalize on your misfortune? Should they go easy and give you an unwarranted mercy? If you're trying desperately to win, would you not go hard on them and count the miss? 

Uncertainty is an aspect of almost any game not devoted to pure strategy. Learning to expect unfavourable rng is a skill, and so is knowing that you cannot depend on it completely.

WAIT! Crit management is a thing?! That's awesome!

Kind of, but not really. There is a system that could theoretically allow it, but there are safeguards built into that system to prevent crit manipulation. The reason it theoretically works is because the game uses psuedo-RNG, which is a way of normalizing crit outcomes to limit the impact of RNG screwing someone. It does this by starting you at a lower value than your actual crit chance for your first attack, then building it up as you attack without getting crits. As an example, if I had 50% crit chance, my first attack might only have a 25% chance to crit (that is not the actual number), which then goes up by 20% every time I don't crit. I still end up with a 50% chance to crit over a large number of attacks (again, not with these example numbers), but with much less variance. Theoretically, we could use this to autoattack creeps a few times, then go all-in if we didn't get a crit on the minions because a first-hit crit on the enemy is much more likely now.

However, with the way the game actually works, you can't really get much from doing this. From what we've been told in the past, there is a mechanism in the formula to mitigate crit manipulation. This likely means that the crit chance for minions and champions is independent (so you can't build crit chance on minions), or that crit chance is independent on all targets, or that starting to crit then canceling your autoattacking to not lose your crit chance actually will burn the crit chance. We don't know exactly it is, but we do know that doing this generally has very small potential rewards, particularly as crit chance goes up and variance goes down.

I've canceled a crit animation and not gotten a crit on the next attack before, both on minions.

As for the hitting minions and going for champs, I do this sometimes, and it seems to work okay. If I have 15-20% crit and I don't get one in 4 to 6 autos, I'll go in for a trade and usually crit.
